post_text: New Directions Learning Academy is under new leadership this school year, with veteran Dorchester County Public Schools educator Dr. Teresa Berry as Interim Principal. Dr. Berry is a familiar face in the county, having served in a variety of posts in a variety of schools over the past 25 years: social studies teacher, In-School Suspension Coordinator, Dean of Students, Assistant Principal, and Pupil Personnel Worker at Mace’s Lane Middle School, Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, Sandy Hill Elementary School, and North Dorchester Middle School. Dr. Berry has grabbed her new assignment with gusto, saying, “I can already tell that NDLA is a unique and special place that I am incredibly excited to become part of.” Not one to stand still, she says, “I am devoted to continually exploring new ideas to meet the needs of all students and to interact with parents and community members more efficiently.” We look forward to seeing NDLA benefit from your enthusiasm and experience, Dr. Berry! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: The Judy Center at Sandy Hill is welcoming a new Coordinator this school year, Dr. Emma Pinkett. Dr. Pinkett, formerly known as Choptank Elementary’s principal Ms. Pinkett, is taking her newly-earned doctorate along with her 25 years of experience in Dorchester County Public Schools to The Judy Center, allowing our littlest learners to benefit from her expertise. Previously an elementary teacher, Assistant Principal, and Principal, Dr. Pinkett says, “All children can learn but at different paces. We have to give them the space and time to learn.” Although Judy Center activities will necessarily look different than previous years, Dr. Pinkett says she is determined to “learn what I need to know to take The Judy Center to the next level.” Welcome to The Judy Center and your new challenge, Dr. Pinkett! #WeAreOneDCPS

Dorchester County Public Schools’ reopening plan is now complete and off to the Maryland State Department of Education. Whew! Thank you to the staff, parents, and community stakeholders who worked on the three committees to hammer out the way forward. The full plan can be accessed on the DCPS website at
http://www.dcps.k12.md.us/news/news-archives/item/435-dorchester-county-public-schools-re-opening-plan. Parents are encouraged to read the plan which will answer some questions, such as specific schedules for different grades, but many details are still being worked out, particularly in the areas of electronic device distribution and food distribution. Here are some general guidelines: School starts September 8 for all grades; all instruction is virtual, with live lessons Tuesday through Friday and online work on Monday; school-issued electronic devices will be available for all students in K through 12th grade; and there will be meal distribution. More details will be released as they are finalized, so stay tuned! #WeAreOneDCPS #ComingBackStrongDCPS

post_text: Twenty-eight years ago Choptank Elementary’s new principal Laretha Payton began her education career as a kindergarten teacher in Fayetteville, North Carolina, and while she has had successful forays into both middle and high school, she is happy to be back in an elementary school where it all began. Joining Dorchester County Public Schools in 2017, Ms. Payton first taught at Mace’s Lane Middle School and for the last two years has been an Assistant Principal at Cambridge-South Dorchester High. Her educational philosophy? “I believe that all students can learn when given equal and equitable opportunities,” she says. Going forward, Ms. Payton says she looks forward to continuing to lead the Choptank Elementary community “in providing the best learning environment for Choptank students.” A big welcome to the newest hummingbird, Ms. Laretha Payton! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: Mace’s Lane Middle School’s new principal won’t have any trouble finding his way around the building as this is his second tenure as a Tiger. Now in his 39th year in education and his 21st as a principal in a DCPS school, Mr. Evans’ guiding philosophy remains the same: “What’s best for the children?” He says, “If everyone has that same mentality, you can’t have anything but success in a school.” And, of course, we wish Mr. Evans nothing but success in his new role! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: If the new principal at Dorchester Career and Technology Center looks familiar, that’s because Anna Howie spent 16 years in Dorchester County Public Schools before her recent two-year interlude in Talbot County. But Ms. Howie is back and ready to rock on for DCTC students! Originally a math teacher at Maces Lane Middle School, Ms. Howie served as an Instructional Math Coach, Assistant Human Resources Administrator, Local Area Coordinator, and Supervisor of Math for DCPS and is now Supervisor of Career and Technical Education as well as DCTC principal. Her future plans for DCTC? She looks forward to supporting the expansion of the Maryland Apprenticeship Program and more business partnerships, as well as ensuring that younger students are in the know about the great opportunities at DCTC. “I want to expose elementary students to what’s available in this building, as well Gateway to Technology in middle school,” she says. Welcome back to DCPS, Ms. Howie! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: A big welcome to Dave Stofa, the new principal at North Dorchester High School, who has now made it a hat trick in mid-shore education having worked in Caroline, Talbot, and now Dorchester County during his extensive career. The former Easton High School principal, fresh off a stint at the Central Office of Talbot County Public Schools, is excited about landing at The Nest as a newly-minted Eagle. His plan out of the gate is one of communicating “firm expectations” to the students, with a top priority of “keeping students and staff safe” in these unusual times. His key words about his leadership of the school? “Caring, passionate about kids, and relentless in ensuring kids and staff get what they need.” A proven advocate for his students, we are delighted to welcome Mr. Stofa to Dorchester County Public Schools! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: The SkillsUSA chapter at Dorchester Career and Technology Center has done it again! For the third year in a row, the local chapter has been awarded one of SkillsUSA’s highest accolades, the Gold Chapter of Distinction, one of only two of Maryland's 50+ chapters to earn this designation. This award recognizes the chapter’s outstanding achievement in the integration of the SkillsUSA Framework – the application of personal, workplace, and technical skills - in chapter activities, such as the Childhood Nutrition Day conducted at Sandy Hill Elementary and an event in conjunction with the Dorchester County Chamber of Commerce involving mock interviews for DCTC and CSD students and a panel discussion of leading business people, both pictured below. post_text: Important information for all Dorchester County Public Schools parents: the Maryland Department of Human Services and Maryland State Department of Education have partnered to issue a new benefit to help with family food costs. The Pandemic-Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) will give DCPS parents access to up to $370.50 per child to be used for the purchase of food. Those parents already holding EBT cards will have payment added to their card during June. Those without EBT cards will be receiving one card via mail before the end of June for each child registered as a student with DCPS on March 13, 2020. post_text: What do trapeze artistry and beekeeping have in common with working with children? The need for courage, confidence, and focus. Katie Crucillo, a DE Education Support Professional of the Year finalist has taken lessons with both a trapeze and bees (not at the same time!), which can only add to what she brings to her role as an Instructional Assistant (Highly Qualified) working with Special Education students at Vienna Elementary. Her work involves helping students learn life skills and participate in activities with their peers, creating visual materials to help students communicate, and tracking student progress towards IEP goals, which Ms. Crucillo terms “incredibly rewarding”. Ms. Crucillo has a B.S. in Psychology from Towson University and has worked with DCPS since 2012, although this is her first year at Vienna, where she is happy to be because, “I love how welcoming the staff was and the overall joy of the working environment.” Our kiddos need people with courage, confidence, and focus in our schools, and we’re glad Ms. Crucillo is there for them! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: Hello from The Peace Team! The Peace Team is a group of professionally trained mediators from Mid Shore Community Mediation Center who provide conflict resolution services for DCPS students, staff, and families. They have offices at MLMS, NDMS, NDHS, and CSD (and will work in other schools by request) and is available Monday through Friday 8:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Their role is to help people resolve conflicts through a voluntary, nonjudgmental, and private mediation process. The Peace Team has been an essential DCPS partner since 2011, receiving more than 400 requests for mediation last year. During the school closure, The Peace Team is providing mediation online. They have also set up a “Listening Line” for anyone who needs to talk – whether it’s to decompress and let go of some stress or to get some help dealing with a conflict. To contact the Peace Team, email schools@midshoremediation.org or call 410-820-5553 and leave a message. #InThisTogether #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: The first year of teaching is a time of great learning and growth, of frustration and occasional despair, of immense joy and satisfaction … sometimes, all in the same day! We celebrate all our first year teachers because we know how challenging it can be. post_text: Today’s First Class Teacher of the Year finalist actually credits one of our Teacher of the Year finalists for instilling a love of learning and intensifying her dream of becoming a teacher. Hannah Abt was a student in the Early Childhood program at Dorchester Career and Technology Center and says she was inspired by her teacher there, Cherie Robinson’s, “love of children and passion for educating young minds.” After graduating from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, Ms. Abt earned a degree from Salisbury University and returned here to her home county to teach Pre-Kindergarten at Choptank Elementary. What has her first year of teaching taught her? “It is never too late to try something new, whether it is a classroom management strategy, teaching strategy, planning strategy, or reworking the lesson you had planned midway through teaching it. Try new things until you find something that works for you and your students.” We’re happy you’re here in Dorchester County, Ms. Abt, and hope this is only the beginning of a long relationship! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: To look at her, you would find it hard to believe that today’s Teacher of the Year finalist has been teaching since at least 1995. But that’s around the time Valerie Friedel began spending her weekends at the library checking out books and setting up a school in her living room with her dolls and Barbies as students. Luckily for us, the Pre-kindergarten teacher eventually moved on to real, live students and has now been teaching at Sandy Hill Elementary School for six years. While being a teacher had always been her dream, Ms. Friedel says, “Throughout my school years, having had many great teachers, my desire to become a teacher grew even stronger. I knew teaching was the career I needed!” We can thank the teachers of DCPS for that inspiration as our finalist grew up right here in Dorchester County. And thank you, Ms. Friedel, for accepting the torch from those who came before you and who knows? You might right now be inspiring another child who is sitting in the living room teaching their dolls and Barbies! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: Megan Day is another example of someone whose own school experience laid the foundation for her teaching career. The Teacher of the Year finalist remembers when she was struggling with reading, her 2nd grade teacher never made her feel like she couldn’t do what her classmates could do. “She made sure I had the tools I needed to be successful and went above and beyond to catch me up in reading,” Ms. Day says. Now, Ms. Day is the EL teacher at Maple Elementary School, working with English learners in their kindergarten through 4th grade classrooms. In her sixth year with Dorchester County Public Schools, Ms. Day has a degree from Chesapeake College as well as Bachelor and Master’s degrees from Salisbury University. Her philosophy when working with her young students? “Never limit a child because of what they cannot do YET,“ she says. “Instead, help them overcome those barriers so they can have a successful future.” Thank you, Ms. Day, for helping ensure all our students have an equitable opportunity for success! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: The first year of teaching is not only a time for teaching but a time for learning . . . a lot. So says First Class Teacher of the Year finalist Meredith Whitten, a 4th grade teacher at Sandy Hill Elementary School. She says, “I have learned that teaching is by far not an easy profession. I have learned that having flexibility becomes a crucial part of your job every day as you are constantly making decisions to best fit your students’ needs. I have also learned that I am not just a teacher, I am a nurturer in my students’ lives, and their biggest cheerleader in life.” A graduate of North Dorchester High School, Ms. Whitten dreamed of becoming a teacher since she was a little girl because helping students learn and “become the future” is such a joy. And just to show she can’t get enough of teaching, Ms. Whitten also teaches dance at the Eastern Shore Dance Academy, having been dancing herself since the age of three. Thank you, Ms. Whitten, for sharing your love for teaching with Dorchester County children! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: Dedication, discipline, strength, flexibility. These are all necessary characteristics of a skilled gymnast. This may be why JoAnn Dechert has been such a success in the classroom. Today’s Teacher of the Year finalist was a competitive gymnast for ten years, a gymnastics judge during her four years of college, and has coached the sport for 17 years. For the last 29 years she has applied these attributes and more in a Dorchester County classroom, the most recent 24 years at Vienna Elementary School, currently in kindergarten. Ms. Dechert grew up in Dorchester County and graduated from Cambridge-South Dorchester High School before heading to Salisbury University to earn her B.S. in Elementary Education, and later a Master’s degree too. She says, “Teaching is the most rewarding profession! I truly get to make a difference every day in the lives of the children I teach. Teaching has always been more than a job for me – it is part of who I am.” Thank you, Ms. Dechert, for sharing that part of who you are for so many years with so many children in Dorchester County! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: So how busy is the average day for today’s Teacher of the Year finalist? Not only does she have a classroom of 5th graders to look after, but also a son, a daughter, two goats, two ducks, eight chickens, a rabbit, two dogs and a cat. But even with all of this, Hurlock Elementary’s Ashley Parker loves every minute of her school life: “I love being someone’s ‘reason’ to come to school. It gives me a sense of purpose, and on those very stressful days, reminds me why I chose this incredible path in life.” A graduate of Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, Ms. Parker has been with Dorchester County Public Schools for ten years, the first eight of them at Maple Elementary before moving to Hurlock two years ago. Her teaching philosophy is ‘tough love’ and says, “Children need a healthy balance of high expectations and consistent classroom routines, but deserve to be part of a classroom where they feel loved, valued, and safe.” Thank you, Ms. Parker, for sharing your considerable energy and enthusiasm with our Dorchester County children! #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: When things just aren’t adding up, who are you going to call? Teacher of the Year finalist Amanda Robinson, who teaches Algebra 1 and 2, Geometry, and Pre-Calculus at North Dorchester High School, would be a good place to start! A Dorchester County native, Ms. Robinson has Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in Mathematics Education and while this is her first year at the high school, she taught at North Dorchester Middle School for 12 years so already knows many of her students. Helping people understand math since she was in 5th grade, Ms. Robinson said, “I always felt like I could explain math in a simplified way and help people around me succeed.” Her ambitions for her students? “I want the students in my class to work hard and be kind. They will be the ones taking care of us when we get older, so I want to help make our community the best for my family.” Thank you for the investment you are making in your community, Ms. Robinson, by teaching in our schools! (The photos show what teaching looks like for our teachers in April 2020!) #WeAreOneDCPS

post_text: Teacher of the Year finalist Erin King says she and her family are “Disney obsessed” because they love the magic of Disney, a magic that allows her to “have fun, take chances and not take life too seriously”. Isn’t that the kind of teacher with whom you would love to learn? Ms. King is a special education teacher at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, working with 9th through 12th grade students. Another homegrown educator, she attended Dorchester County Public Schools, graduated with a degree in sociology from Salisbury University and went on to earn a graduate degree in Special Education Assessment and Instruction from Walden University. She started her career working with teens in a counseling setting, but felt she needed to take a different approach in order to be effective, and that’s what led her to teaching with us 15 years ago. And we at Dorchester County Public Schools are very glad it did! #WeAreOneDCPS
